question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Every card in a deck has a picture of one shape - circle, square, or triangle, which is painted in one of the three colors - red, blue, or green. Furthermore, each color is applied in one of three shades - light, medium, or dark. The deck has 27 cards, with every shape-color-shade combination represented. A set of three cards from the deck is called complementary if all of the following statements are true:
i. Either each of the three cards has a different shape or all three of the card have the same shape.
ii. Either each of the three cards has a different color or all three of the cards have the same color.
iii. Either each of the three cards has a different shade or all three of the cards have the same shade.
How many different complementary three-card sets are there?
inference:
There are 3 choices for shape, 3 choices for color, and 3 choices for shade.  So there are $3 \times 3 \times 3 = 27$ possible cards.
For a set of three cards to be complementary, either the shapes are all different or all the same, the colors are all different or all the same, and the shades are all different or all the same.
There are 3 choices for each card's shape, 3 choices for color, and 3 choices for shade.  Thus there are $3 \times 3 \times 3 = 27$ possible cards.  This means there are $27$ cards in the deck.

Case 1: All three shapes are the same.  There are 3 choices for shape.  Then there are $3 \times 3 = 9$ choices for color/shade.  Then we have $3^2 = 9$ ways to choose the colors and $3^2=9$ ways to choose the shades.
If the shapes are the same, we have $3$ choices for shape.  For the colors, we have $3$ choices (all the same color), and for the shades, we have $3$ choices (all the same shade).  There are $3$ possible choices for the shape, color, and shade.  So, there are $3 \times 1 \times 1 = 3$ sets where the shape is the same.  For the color/shade, there are $3 \times 3 \times 3 = 27$ possible sets.
There are $3^3$ ways to choose all three cards with the same shape, color, or shade.  $3 \times 1 \times 1 = 3$ for same shape.  $3^2 = 9$ choices for color/shade.  $3^2 = 9$ choices for color/shade.  $3 \times 1 \times 1 = 3$.

Case 1: Same shape, same color, same shade. $3 \times 3 \times 3 = 27$.
Case 2: Same shape, different color, different shade.  We choose 3 cards that all have the same shape.  There are 3 choices for shape.  For the colors, there are $\binom{3}{3} = 1$ way to choose 3 distinct colors. For the shades, there are $\binom{3}{3} = 1$ way to choose 3 distinct shades.
There are 3 choices for the shape. Then there are $\binom{3}{3} = 1$ way to choose 3 different colors. Then there are $\binom{3}{3} = 1$ way to choose 3 different shades.  So there are $3 \times 1 \times 1 = 3$ choices.  For each choice of shape, there are $3 \times 1 \times 1 = 3$ ways.
$3 \times 3^2 = 3 \times 9 = 27$.  This is not correct.

Case 1: All shapes the same.  We have 3 shapes.  For the colors, there are 3 choices.  There are 3 choices for shades.  So we have $3 \times 1 \times 1 = 3$ sets of cards with the same shape.  $3 \times 3 \times 3 = 27$.
$3 \times 1 \times 1 = 3$ ways.  $3 \times 3 \times 3 = 27$
$3 \times 1 \times 1 = 3 \times 1 \times 1 = 3$ ways for same shape.

Number of ways to have different shape, same color, same shade. $3 \times 3 \times 1 = 9$ ways for different shape and same color, same shade. $3^3 = 27$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{27}$
ground_truth:
Case 1: All three attributes are the same. This is impossible since sets contain distinct cards.
Case 2: Two of the three attributes are the same. There are ${3\choose 2}$ ways to pick the two attributes in question. Then there are $3$ ways to pick the value of the first attribute, $3$ ways to pick the value of the second attribute, and $1$ way to arrange the positions of the third attribute, giving us ${3\choose 2} \cdot 3 \cdot 3 = 27$ ways.
Case 3: One of the three attributes are the same. There are ${3\choose 1}$ ways to pick the one attribute in question, and then $3$ ways to pick the value of that attribute. Then there are $3!$ ways to arrange the positions of the next two attributes, giving us ${3\choose 1} \cdot 3 \cdot 3! = 54$ ways.
Case 4: None of the three attributes are the same. We fix the order of the first attribute, and then there are $3!$ ways to pick the ordering of the second attribute and $3!$ ways to pick the ordering of the third attribute. This gives us $(3!)^2 = 36$ ways.
Adding the cases up, we get $27 + 54 + 36 = \boxed{117}$.

Case 1: All three attributes are the same. This is impossible since sets contain distinct cards.
Case 2: Two of the three attributes are the same. There are ${3\choose 2}$ ways to pick the two attributes in question. Then there are $3$ ways to pick the value of the first attribute, $3$ ways to pick the value of the second attribute, and $1$ way to arrange the positions of the third attribute, giving us ${3\choose 2} \cdot 3 \cdot 3 = 27$ ways.
Case 3: One of the three attributes are the same. There are ${3\choose 1}$ ways to pick the one attribute in question, and then $3$ ways to pick the value of that attribute. Then there are $3!$ ways to arrange the positions of the next two attributes, giving us ${3\choose 1} \cdot 3 \cdot 3! = 54$ ways.
Case 4: None of the three attributes are the same. We fix the order of the first attribute, and then there are $3!$ ways to pick the ordering of the second attribute and $3!$ ways to pick the ordering of the third attribute. This gives us $(3!)^2 = 36$ ways.
Adding the cases up, we get $27 + 54 + 36 = \boxed{117}$.
